001package imagingbook.pub.dft;
002
003import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
004
005import org.jtransforms.fft.DoubleFFT_1D;
006import org.jtransforms.fft.FloatFFT_1D;
007
008/**
009 * FFT (fast) implementation of the DFT, based on the JTransforms package
010 * by Piotr Wendykier (see <a href="https://github.com/wendykierp/JTransforms">
011 * https://github.com/wendykierp/JTransforms</a>).
012 */
013public abstract class Dft1dFast {
014        
015        final int M;                    // size (length) of the signal or spectrum
016        final ScalingMode sm;   
017        
018        private Dft1dFast(int M, ScalingMode sm) {
019                this.M = M;
020                this.sm = sm;
021        }
022        
023        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
024        
025        /**
026         * One-dimensional FFT implementation using single precision (float) data. 
027         */
028        public static class Float extends Dft1dFast implements Dft1d.Float {
029        
030                private final float[] A;                // temporary array for FFT composed of re/im values
031                private final FloatFFT_1D fft;
032                
033                public Float(int M, ScalingMode sm) {
034                        super(M, sm);
035                        this.A = new float[2 * M];
036                        this.fft = new FloatFFT_1D(M);
037                }
038                
039                public Float(int M) {
040                        this(M, ScalingMode.DEFAULT);
041                }
042                
043                @Override
044                public void forward(float[] gRe, float[] gIm) {
045                        checkSize(gRe, gIm, M);
046//                      float scale = (float) sm.getScale(M, true);
047//                      setupA(gRe, gIm, A);    
048//                      fft.complexForward(A);
049//                      decompA(A, gRe, gIm, scale);
050                        transform(gRe, gIm, true);
051                }
052                
053                @Override
054                public void inverse(float[] GRe, float[] GIm) {
055                        checkSize(GRe, GIm, M);
056//                      float scale = (float) sm.getScale(M, false);
057//                      setupA(GRe, GIm, A);    
058//                      fft.complexInverse(A, false);
059//                      decompA(A, GRe, GIm, scale);
060                        transform(GRe, GIm, false);
061                }
062                
063                public void transform(float[] inRe, float[] inIm, boolean forward) {
064                        checkSize(inRe, inIm, M);
065                        final float scale = (float) sm.getScale(M, forward);
066                        setupA(inRe, inIm, A);  
067                        if (forward)
068                                fft.complexForward(A);
069                        else
070                                fft.complexInverse(A, false);
071                        decompA(A, inRe, inIm, scale);
072                }
073                
074                // (re, im) -> A
075                private void setupA(float[] re, float[] im, float[] A) {
076                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
077                                A[2*i] = re[i];
078                                A[2*i + 1] = im[i];
079                        }
080                }
081                
082                // A -> (re, im)
083                private void decompA(float[] A, float[] re, float[] im, float scale) {
084                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
085                                re[i] = A[2*i] * scale;
086                                im[i] = A[2*i + 1] * scale;
087                        }
088                }
089        }
090        
091        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
092        
093        /**
094         * One-dimensional FFT implementation using double precision data. 
095         */
096        public static class Double extends Dft1dFast implements Dft1d.Double{
097        
098                private final double[] A;               // temporary array for FFT composed of re/im values
099                private final DoubleFFT_1D fft;
100                
101                public Double(int M, ScalingMode sm) {
102                        super(M, sm);
103                        this.A = new double[2 * M];
104                        this.fft = new DoubleFFT_1D(M);
105                }
106                
107                public Double(int M) {
108                        this(M, ScalingMode.DEFAULT);
109                }
110                
111                @Override
112                public void forward(double[] gRe, double[] gIm) {
113                        checkSize(gRe, gIm, M);
114//                      double scale = sm.getScale(M, true);
115//                      setupA(gRe, gIm, A);    
116//                      fft.complexForward(A);
117//                      decompA(A, gRe, gIm, scale);
118                        transform(gRe, gIm, true);
119                }
120                
121                @Override
122                public void inverse(double[] GRe, double[] GIm) {
123                        checkSize(GRe, GIm, M);
124//                      double scale = sm.getScale(M, false);
125//                      setupA(GRe, GIm, A);    
126//                      fft.complexInverse(A, false);
127//                      decompA(A, GRe, GIm, scale);
128                        transform(GRe, GIm, false);
129                }
130                
131                @Override
132                public void transform(double[] inRe, double[] inIm, boolean forward) {
133                        checkSize(inRe, inIm, M);
134                        final double scale = (double) sm.getScale(M, forward);
135                        setupA(inRe, inIm, A);  
136                        if (forward)
137                                fft.complexForward(A);
138                        else
139                                fft.complexInverse(A, false);
140                        decompA(A, inRe, inIm, scale);
141                }
142                
143                // (re, im) -> A
144                private void setupA(double[] re, double[] im, double[] A) {
145                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
146                                A[2*i] = re[i];
147                                A[2*i + 1] = im[i];
148                        }
149                }
150                
151                // A -> (re, im)
152                private void decompA(double[] A, double[] re, double[] im, double scale) {
153                        for (int i = 0; i < M; i++) {
154                                re[i] = A[2*i] * scale;
155                                im[i] = A[2*i + 1] * scale;
156                        }
157                }
158        }
159
160        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
161
162        /*
163         * Direct implementation of the one-dimensional DFT for arbitrary signal lengths.
164         * This DFT uses the same definition as Mathematica. Example:
165         * Fourier[{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8}, FourierParameters -> {0, -1}]:
166                {12.7279 + 0. i, 
167                -1.41421 + 3.41421 i, 
168                -1.41421 + 1.41421 i, 
169                -1.41421 + 0.585786 i, 
170                -1.41421 + 0. i, 
171                -1.41421 - 0.585786 i, 
172                -1.41421 - 1.41421 i, 
173                -1.41421 - 3.41421 i}
174         */
175
176        //test example
177        public static void main(String[] args) {
178
179                System.out.println("******************** Float test (FFT) ********************");
180                {
181                        float[] re = { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 };
182                        float[] im = new float[re.length];
183
184                        System.out.println("original signal:");
185                        System.out.println("gRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
186                        System.out.println("gIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
187
188                        Dft1d.Float dft = new Dft1dFast.Float(re.length);
189                        dft.forward(re, im);
190//                      float[] GRe = dft.getRe();
191//                      float[] GIm = dft.getIm();
192
193                        System.out.println("DFT spectrum:");
194                        System.out.println("GRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
195                        System.out.println("GIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
196
197                        dft.inverse(re, im);
198
199                        System.out.println("reconstructed signal:");
200                        System.out.println("gRe' = " + Matrix.toString(re));
201                        System.out.println("gIm' = " + Matrix.toString(im));
202                }
203                
204                System.out.println();
205                System.out.println("******************** Double test (FFT) ********************");
206
207                {
208                        double[] re = { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 };
209                        double[] im = new double[re.length];
210
211                        System.out.println("original signal:");
212                        System.out.println("gRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
213                        System.out.println("gIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
214
215                        Dft1d.Double dft = new Dft1dFast.Double(re.length);
216                        dft.forward(re, im);
217
218                        System.out.println("DFT spectrum:");
219                        System.out.println("GRe = " + Matrix.toString(re));
220                        System.out.println("GIm = " + Matrix.toString(im));
221
222                        dft.inverse(re, im);
223
224                        System.out.println("reconstructed signal:");
225                        System.out.println("gRe' = " + Matrix.toString(re));
226                        System.out.println("gIm' = " + Matrix.toString(im));
227                }
228        }
229
230}
